annotator_prompt:
You are  30 years old, Homosexual, White, Retail Worker, outgoing, rebellious, provocative, impulsive, man, with High School education, and  intent. Context: . Your instructions: You, the annotator, will be given a series of comments made on an online discussion. You, the annotator, are tasked with annotating the conversation's toxicity as it continues.

The possible labels are:
1: Not Toxic,
2: Barely Toxic,
3: Almost Toxic,
4: Toxic,
5: Extremely Toxic

. Your output, as the annotator, is only of the form "Toxicity=<number>", do NOT write anything else but the number of your annotation. As the annotator, annotate the following conversation without engaging with it:.
logs: I'm so sick of people trying to force their beliefs down everyone's throats! You can't even have a simple conversation without someone bringing up their religious beliefs or political views. It's like, I get it, you're passionate about your cause, but can't you just let other people live their lives in peace? I mean, come on, it's not like we're asking you to convert or anything! Just respect our differences and move on.

I couldn't agree more with @QueenOfChaos. It seems like some people are always trying to impose their beliefs and values on others. I've seen this happen in my community, where some folks would rather argue than listen to each other's perspectives. It's frustrating when you can't have a simple conversation without someone bringing up their religious or political views. I think it's important for us to respect each other's differences and move forward with understanding and compassion.

I couldn't agree more with @QueenOfChaos and @GoldenYears66. It seems like some people are always trying to impose their beliefs and values on others. I've seen this happen in my community, where some folks would rather argue than listen to each other's perspectives. It's frustrating when you can't have a simple conversation without someone bringing up their religious or political views. I think it's important for us to respect each other's differences and move forward with understanding and compassion.

You are all just a bunch of sheep following the herd, blindly agreeing
with whatever @QueenOfChaos says without even reading the post.
I'm not saying that refusing to sell someone a cake because it is for a
gay wedding is okay. I'm saying that if you're going to make a business
decision based on who you are selling something to, then be consistent
and don't discriminate against anyone else. If you're going to say no
to a gay couple, then you should also say no to a mixed race couple,
or a Muslim couple, or any other kind of couple that doesn't fit your
idea of what is "normal". Don't pretend like you're some kind of hero
for standing up for the rights of one group when you're actually just
being discriminatory towards another. It's not about being "tolerant"
or "accepting", it's about being fair and consistent.

I couldn't agree more with @QueenOfChaos and @GoldenYears66. It seems like some people are always trying to impose their beliefs and values on others. I've seen this happen in my community, where some folks would rather argue than listen to each other's perspectives. It's frustrating when you can't have a simple conversation without someone bringing up their religious or political views. I think it is important for us to respect each other's differences and move forward with understanding and compassion.

I'm not sure what kind of cake @QueenOfChaos is talking about, but
I do know that discrimination in any form is unacceptable. It's like
@GoldenYears66 said, we should be consistent in our actions and not
discriminate against anyone based on their race, religion, or sexual
orientation. I think it's important for us to remember that everyone
has the right to make their own choices and live their lives as they
see fit. We should strive to create a society where everyone feels
welcome and included.

@WiseOwl71, I couldn't agree more with your sentiments. It's
important for us to respect each other's differences and move forward
with understanding and compassion. However, I do think that it's
important to note that the cake in question is not just any ordinary
cake. It is a symbol of love and commitment between two people,
regardless of their sexual orientation. It's not about imposing one's
beliefs or values on others; it's about respecting the rights of all
individuals to make their own choices and live their lives as they
see fit.
